Award.AwardTitle: Workshop on Diversifying and Deepening Engagement and Learning in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM): Bringing Together Dutch and U.S. Scholars

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This workshop on Diversifying and Deepening Engagement and Learning in STEM will bring together researchers from the United States and the Netherlands to exchange ideas and foster collaboration. Internationally, there is broad recognition that far too narrow a segment of the population is deeply engaged with and knowledgeable about STEM. This narrow engagement negatively affects the prospects of individuals across the globe. Diversifying the pool of children and young adults deeply engaged with STEM, and providing them with well-supported opportunities for deeper learning in STEM, will promote the progress of STEM by positively impacting research and development. Diversity of thought, perspective, experience and quality of preparation improve innovation and the quality of STEM research. The workshop and its products will advance STEM education by enhancing scholars' knowledge of relevant research on diversifying and deepening engagement and learning, and by creating stronger ties among researchers with common interests in and commitment to these issues. STEM education efforts sparked by this workshop will advance national health, prosperity, and welfare by improving individuals' quality of life and enabling broader public participation in democratic processes that are informed by STEM.

The workshop involves a select group of influential scholars from the U.S. and Netherlands whose work contributes to innovative research and development on STEM education both within and beyond schools. The workshop's theme refers to the key goal of diversifying the pool of young people deeply engaged with STEM, including groups historically underrepresented globally and in each nation, while also fostering deeper STEM learning. Throughout the workshop, participants will examine two questions: (1) What are the key social, cultural, and systemic contexts that facilitate and impede broadening STEM participation and learning? (2) How might researchers better understand them, and educators better address them? Comparative work across the U.S. and Netherlands national contexts will allow for bidirectional illumination of issues that might otherwise appear to be merely given or inevitable when examined from a single national standpoint. Gathered scholars will explore the challenges and opportunities for supporting and sustaining interest in, identification with, and deep learning of STEM among young people, through informal and formal learning opportunities. A key outcome of the workshop will be a white paper made freely and widely available to the STEM education community and the general public. The white paper will summarize existing literature and the discussion, framings, and suggestions for further research. The process of constructing and finalizing the white paper will focus the attention of participants in the workshop, and result in greater clarity about the body of theory and research that can inform educational action and future research. In addition, interest groups that form during the workshop will consider pursuing additional products that can inform the STEM education community, such as a journal special issue, an edited volume, research and practice briefs, or other collaborations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In Fall 2018, the Workshop on Diversifying and Deepening Engagement and Learning in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM) brought together researchers from the United States and the Netherlands to exchange ideas and foster collaboration. Internationally, there is broad recognition that far too narrow a segment of the population is deeply engaged with and knowledgeable about STEM. Narrow engagement negatively affects the prospects of individuals across the globe. Diversifying the pool of children and young adults deeply engaged with STEM, and providing them with well-supported opportunities for deeper learning in STEM, will promote progress by positively impacting research and development. Diversity of thought, perspective, experience and quality of preparation improve innovation and the quality of research. 

The workshop involved a select group of influential scholars from the U.S. and the Netherlands whose work contributes to innovative research and development on STEM education within and beyond schools. The workshop's theme refers to the key goal of diversifying the pool of people deeply engaged with STEM, including groups historically underrepresented globally and in each nation, while also fostering deeper STEM learning. Comparative work across the U.S. and Netherlands national contexts allowed for bidirectional illumination of issues that might otherwise appear to be merely given or inevitable when examined from a single national standpoint. Gathered scholars explored the challenges and opportunities for supporting and sustaining interest in, identification with, and deep learning of STEM among young people, through informal and formal learning opportunities. Key outcomes of the workshop included: (1) a greater understanding of meanings of equity and diversity across national and cultural lines, (2) a greater understanding among participants of approaches to deepening engagement with STEM, (3) a greater understanding among participants of approaches to diversifying engagement with STEM, (4) future recommendations for the NSF and the NRO, and (5) a scholarly presentation under review and paper in preparation.

The first three outcomes were a result of participants examining two driving questions throughout the course of the workshop: 

(a) What are the key social, cultural, and systemic contexts that facilitate and impede broadening STEM participation and learning? 

Participants noted factors that facilitate and impede broadening STEM participation and learning. Colonial and settler-colonial histories trouble both nations. In the Netherlands there is unity in end goals expected of students, but diversity in roads different schools travel to prepare students. The Dutch constitution created freedom for schools to decide how learning goals are met and what pedagogical tools to adopt. This diversity in types of schools also creates diversity in teacher professionalization and pedagogy and student/family choices about which school to attend. In the United States, choice and independence in schooling are very political and rooted in economic and colonial foundations. Efforts to create common tools, goals and pedagogical strategies in the US often aims toward the civic goal of social cohesion. 

(b) How might researchers better understand them, and educators better address them? 

Participants stressed the need to create space for students and learners to broaden their agency in STEM endeavors, and to do so equitably across populations. In addition, the need for effective preparation of teachers was discussed. Teachers need to understand the cultural-historical contexts of diverse learners within each society, and of subject matter and how to effectively teach it. In both national contexts, participants saw long-term research-practice partnerships (RPPs) involving school-based or community-based educators and university academics and teacher educators as potentially the most powerful means for transformative change in STEM education over time. These require investment by funders as well as by schools, community-based organizations, and universities. 

The fourth outcome of the workshop was a set of recommendations for the NSF and the NRO. Participants recommend that the organizations consider funding international workshops of this sort in the future in order to help researchers share perspectives, theoretical frameworks, practical tools and resources and to push them out of their comfort zones so they have the opportunity to identify and question some of their unexamined assumptions. Participants also encouraged the NSF and NRO to value and fund the initial work needed to develop collaborative RPPs, as well as fund longer-term projects with opportunities for renewal. Participants encouraged funding agencies to make structural changes for grants to encourage partnerships in under-resourced settings. Finally, participants encouraged agencies to encourage reviewers to recognize that there are more ways to think about broadening participation than the standard ways these are discussed in either US, Dutch, or any one national context.

The fifth outcome are collaborative relations, including a collaborative scholarly symposium presentation currently under review for the AERA 2020 conference entitled ?Windows, Mirrors, Occlusions, Lenses: Bringing Together Dutch and US Perspectives on STEM Education and Equity?, and a paper in preparation entitled ?How Context Frames Equity in Teaching and Learning: Learning from Cultural Rifts and Misunderstandings.? These both involve scholars from both nations.
